title: A high school swimmer who was disqualified over a 'suit wedgie' had the decision overturned
text:
maggee/Shutterstock





A top-rated teen swimmer in Alaska was disqualified over her school-issued swimsuit after she won a race on Friday because the ref claimed it broke regulations.

It did not.

In a statement released Tuesday, the district said it was led to believe that the "swimmer was targeted based solely on how a standard, school-issued uniform happened to fit the shape of her body."

The decision was overturned on Tuesday after the district appealed the decision, the Alaska School Activities Association said.

The Alaska School Activities Association said the decision to overturn the disqualification was made based on "evidence gathered, including the statement provided by the official."

A top-rated teen swimmer in Alaska was disqualified over her school-issued uniform after she won a race on Friday because the referee claimed it broke regulations.

The Anchorage Diamond High School athlete was reprimanded by a referee for having a uniform violation in the form of a "suit wedgie," the Washington Post reported. The teen was wearing a school-issued swimsuit — the same one all of her teammates were wearing.

Following the incident, the school reviewed Friday's swim meet. At the time, the student's coach contested the referee's decision. That request was denied. The Anchorage School District then conducted a review of the incident.

On Tuesday, the district decided to move forward in appealing the swimmer's disqualification.

"Our swimmer was targeted based solely on how a standard, school-issued uniform happened to fit the shape of her body," the district said in a statement. "We cannot tolerate discrimination of any kind, and certainly not based on body shape. This disqualification was heavy-handed and unnecessary."

'This disqualification was heavy-handed and unnecessary.'

The district said it was appealing to the Alaska School Activities Association to reverse the decision and regain lost points; decertify the referee; and revise the National Federation of State High School Associations rule the swimmer was disqualified over because it's "ambiguous and allows the potential for bias to influence officials' decisions."

The rule referenced requires that girls' swimsuits "cover the buttocks and breast," was set by the National Federation of State High School Associations, which presides over high school sports in Alaska.

When it received the appeal, the ASAA agreed. The swimmer's disqualification was overturned.

In a statement, the ASAA said it reversed the decision because of a rule that states officials must notify coaches when they become aware of uniform violations.

"All evidence gathered, including the statement provided by the official, indicated the official did not notify the coach prior to disqualifying the student, " the statement said.

Additionally, the swimmer participated in four races during Friday's meet but was only disqualified after one, the Anchorage Daily News reported.

Read more: A high school swimmer was disqualified after winning a race because she had a 'suit wedgie'

This isn't the first time this student's body has been targeted

The teen's mom, Meagan Kowatch, previously told KTUU that this ref had also targeted her younger daughter over the fit of her swimsuit the previous year.

And it's not the first time the teen who was disqualified has been targeted over her body. In September of 2018, another parent took pictures of the girl's backside and sent it to other parents to demonstrate that her swimwear was "inappropriate," the Washington Post reported.

The school district has released a full timeline of events. They noted that at the time, the "assistant principal indicated to the parent who took the photographs that it was not permissible for him to take pictures of others' children and that he should stop immediately."

Lauren Langford, a local swim coach, told the Washington Post that the parent who took those pictures was out of line.

"We have a term for it — it's called a suit wedgie," she said. "And wedgies happen. It's uncomfortable. No one's going to walk around that way intentionally."

description: A referee told a swimmer that her school-issued uniform was inappropriate. Now, the Alaska School Activities Association has overturned that decision.
